DOC.HEADLINE: Roundup: Chinese diplomatic missions, overseas Chinese mourn mudslide victims

TEXT.P: Chinese embassies and consulates worldwide and ethnic Chinese residing overseas held memorial ceremonies on Sunday to mourn the victims of a massive mudslide that killed more than 1,200 people in northwest China.
At the Chinese embassy in Paris, the Chinese national flag was lowered to half mast amid steady drizzle to mourn the victims.
On Sunday morning, the flag was lowered to half mast at the Chinese embassy in Pretoria, South Africa, and staff members observed three minutes' silence for the dead.
China's consulates general in the South African cities of Johannesburg, Durban and Cape Town also held mourning activities.
In Prague, staff at the Chinese embassy in the Czech Republic paid a three- minute silent tribute to the dead.
The Chinese flag was flying at half mast, as Chinese embassy staff members in Sri Lanka stood in silence to mourn for the dead.
With the five-starred flag lowered to half mast, Chinese embassy staff in Ecuador paid a three-minute silent tribute to their compatriots killed in the disaster.

On Sunday morning, the national flag was flown at half mast at the Chinese Consulate-General in San Francisco, the United States. The staff observed three minutes' silence for the victims. China's Consulate-General in Los Angeles also held memorial services.
The Chinese embassy in the United States also held a mourning ceremony on Sunday, with the national flag flying at half mast.
On the same day, the general association of Chinese community in eastern United States held mourning activities in New York and initiated donation for the reconstruction of the disaster-hit region.
The Chinese embassy in Chile also flied the national flag at half mast and held condolence activities on Sunday.
Wang Hexing, chairman of the Chinese business association in Chile, said the overseas Chinese in Chile had paid close attention to the situation in the disaster-hit region and the relief process.
The Chinese embassy in Germany held a mourning ceremony on Sunday to express condolence for the victims in the mudslide.

The national flag was also flown at half mast at the Chinese embassy in Russia. Staff members of the embassy and Chinese companies and institutions there suspended all public entertainment activities.
In Japan, a group of Chinese and Japanese people gathered together at a Sunday Chinese-language corner to express their condolence for the people who are affected in the mudslide.

Duan Yuezhong, president of an overseas Chinese newspaper in Japan, said the overseas Chinese in Japan hope the people in the mudslide-hit Zhouqu begin to resume production and normal life and rebuild their homes as soon as possible.

Ji Yousong, president of the overseas Chinese association in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, said the overseas Chinese wish the compatriots in the mudslide-hit region to tide over the disaster and wish Zhouqu a definitely better future.
Overseas Chinese in the Czech Republic said they were ready to contribute to the reconstruction and believed the people in Zhouqu would conquer the disaster with a strong will for a better future.
The death toll from the Aug. 8 massive mudslide in Zhouqu, northwest China's Gansu province, had risen to 1,254 while 490 were still missing as of 4 p.m. Monday.
China has suffered the worst flooding in a decade this summer. Floods and other rain-induced disasters have so far left more than 2,300 people dead and 1,200 missing nationwide this year.
